item_prototype.name: Current synchronization progress on {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: This shows the number of sectors that have been completed of whatever the current sync_action is, followed by the number of sectors in total that could need to be processed. The two numbers are separated by a '/' thus effectively showing one value, a fraction of the process that is complete.

item_prototype.name: Delay after writes before marking the array as clean on {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: When an md array has seen no write requests for a certain period of time, it will be marked as 'clean'. When another write request arrives, the array is marked as 'dirty' before the write commences. This is known as 'safe_mode'. The 'certain period' is controlled by this file which stores the period as a number of seconds.

item_prototype.name: Maximum speed for RAID rebuilts on {#MDDEV}
Minimum speed for RAID rebuilts on {#MDDEV}
Number is degraded components on {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: This contains a count of the number of devices by which the arrays is degraded. So an optimal array with show '0'. A single failed/missing drive will show '1', etc.

item_prototype.name: Number of errors found while checking or repairing on {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: When performing 'check' and 'repair', and possibly when performing 'resync', md will count the number of errors that are found. The count in 'mismatch_cnt' is the number of sectors that were re-written, or (for 'check') would have been re-written. As most raid levels work in units of pages rather than sectors, this my be larger than the number of actual errors by a factor of the number of sectors in a page.

item_prototype.name: RAID Array state of {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: This file contains a single word which describes the current state of the array. clear / inactive / suspended / readonly / read-auto / clean / active / write-pending / active-idle

item_prototype.name: RAID Array usable size of {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: This can be used to artificially constrain the available space in the array to be less than is actually available on the combined devices.

item_prototype.name: Raid chunk size on {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: This is the size in bytes for 'chunks' and is only relevant to raid levels that involve striping (0,4,5,6,10)

item_prototype.name: RAID Component size on {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: The size of each component of the RAID array (for arrays with data redundancy)

item_prototype.name: Raid disks on {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: The number of devices in a fully functional array

item_prototype.name: Raid layout of {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: The "layout" for the array for the particular level. This is simply a number that is interpretted differently by different levels.

item_prototype.name: RAID Metadata version of {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: This indicates the format that is being used to record metadata about the array. It can be 0.90 (traditional format), 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 (newer format in varying locations) or "none" indicating that the kernel isn't managing metadata at all. Alternately it can be "external:" followed by a string which is set by user-space. This indicates that metadata is managed by a user-space program.

item_prototype.name: RAID Reshape position on {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: This is either "none" or a sector number within the devices of the array where "reshape" is up to.

item_prototype.name: RAID Stripe cache in use on {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: RAID5/6 only: number of active entries in the stripe cache

item_prototype.name: RAID Stripe cache size on {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: RAID5/6 only: Number of entries in the stripe cache.

item_prototype.name: RAID Sync status of {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: It contains one word which can be one of: resync - redundancy is being recalculated after unclean shutdown or creation recover - a hot spare is being built to replace a failed/missing device idle - nothing is happening check - A full check of redundancy was requested and is happening. This reads all block and checks them. A repair may also happen for some raid levels. repair - A full check and repair is happening. This is similar to 'resync', but was requested by the user, and the write-intent bitmap is NOT used to optimise the process.

item_prototype.name: Synchronization speed on {#MDDEV}
item_prototype.description: This shows the current actual speed, in K/sec, of the current sync_action. It is averaged over the last 30 seconds.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template App MD Raid:md[{#MDDEV},array_state].str(inactive)}=1 | {Template App MD Raid:md[{#MDDEV},array_state].str(suspended)}=1 | {Template App MD Raid:md[{#MDDEV},array_state].str(readonly)}=1 | {Template App MD Raid:md[{#MDDEV},array_state].str(clear)}=1
trigger_prototype.name: Array state: {Template App MD Raid:md[{#MDDEV},array_state]
trigger_prototype.description: The RAID array is a problem state

trigger_prototype.name: Number of RAID disks in {#MDDEV} changed from {ITEM.LASTVALUE1} to {ITEM.VALUE1}
RAID array {#MDDEV} is repairing
trigger_prototype.description: A full check and repair is happening. This is similar to 'resync', but was requested by the user, and the write-intent bitmap is NOT used to optimise the process.

trigger_prototype.name: RAID level of {#MDDEV} changed from {ITEM.LASTVALUE1} to {ITEM.VALUE1}
RAID usage size changed from {ITEM.LASTVALUE1} to {ITEM.VALUE1}
